sn56.31:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati sīsapāvane.
sn56.31:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī in a rosewood forest.

sn56.31:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittāni sīsapāpaṇṇāni pāṇinā gahetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn56.31:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha picked up a few rosewood leaves in his hand and addressed the mendicants:

sn56.31:1.5.pli: yāni vā mayā parittāni sīsapāpaṇṇāni pāṇinā gahitāni yadidaṃ upari sīsapāvane”ti?
sn56.31:1.5.eng: the few leaves in my hand, or those in the forest above me?”

sn56.31:1.6.pli: “Appamattakāni, bhante, bhagavatā parittāni sīsapāpaṇṇāni pāṇinā gahitāni;
sn56.31:1.6.eng: “Sir, the few leaves in your hand are a tiny amount.

sn56.31:1.7.pli: atha kho etāneva bahutarāni yadidaṃ upari sīsapāvane”ti.
sn56.31:1.7.eng: There are far more leaves in the forest above.”

sn56.31:1.8.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, etadeva bahutaraṃ yaṃ vo mayā abhiññāya anakkhātaṃ.
sn56.31:1.8.eng: “In the same way, there is much more that I have directly known but have not explained to you. What I have explained is a tiny amount.

sn56.31:1.9.eng: And why haven’t I explained it?

sn56.31:1.10.pli: Na hetaṃ, bhikkhave, atthasaṃhitaṃ nādibrahmacariyakaṃ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati;
sn56.31:1.10.eng: Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.31:1.11.eng: That’s why I haven’t explained it.

sn56.31:2.2.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhan’ti, bhikkhave, mayā akkhātaṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti mayā akkhātaṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti mayā akkhātaṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti mayā akkhātaṃ.
sn56.31:2.2.eng: I have explained: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.31:3.1.eng: And why have I explained this?

sn56.31:3.2.pli: Etañhi, bhikkhave, atthasaṃhitaṃ etaṃ ādibrahmacariyakaṃ etaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati;
sn56.31:3.2.eng: Because it’s beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.31:4.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.31:4.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.32:1.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca, dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca sammā dukkhassantaṃ karissāmī’ti—
sn56.32:1.2.eng: ‘Without truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’

sn56.32:2.1.eng: It’s as if someone were to say:

sn56.32:2.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ khadirapattānaṃ vā saralapattānaṃ vā āmalakapattānaṃ vā puṭaṃ karitvā udakaṃ vā tālapattaṃ vā āharissāmī’ti—
sn56.32:2.2.eng: ‘I’ll make a basket out of acacia leaves or pine needles or myrobalan leaves, and use it to carry water or a palm frond.’

sn56.32:2.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yo evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.32:2.4.eng: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:

sn56.32:2.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca sammā dukkhassantaṃ karissāmī’ti—
sn56.32:2.5.eng: ‘Without truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’

sn56.32:3.1.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.32:3.1.eng: But suppose someone were to say:

sn56.32:3.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca, dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca sammā dukkhassantaṃ karissāmī’ti—
sn56.32:3.2.eng: ‘After truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’

sn56.32:4.1.eng: It’s as if someone were to say:

sn56.32:4.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ padumapattānaṃ vā palāsapattānaṃ vā māluvapattānaṃ vā puṭaṃ karitvā udakaṃ vā tālapattaṃ vā āharissāmī’ti—
sn56.32:4.2.eng: ‘I’ll make a basket out of lotus leaves or flame-of-the-forest leaves or camel’s foot creeper leaves, and use it to carry water or a palm frond.’

sn56.32:4.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yo evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.32:4.4.eng: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:

sn56.32:4.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca sammā dukkhassantaṃ karissāmī’ti—
sn56.32:4.5.eng: ‘After truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’

sn56.32:5.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.32:5.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.33:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, daṇḍo uparivehāsaṃ khitto sakimpi mūlena nipatati, sakimpi aggena nipatati;
sn56.33:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a stick was tossed up in the air. Sometimes it’d fall on its bottom and sometimes the top.

sn56.33:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjānīvaraṇā sattā taṇhāsaṃyojanā sandhāvantā saṃsarantā sakimpi asmā lokā paraṃ lokaṃ gacchanti, sakimpi parasmā lokā imaṃ lokaṃ āgacchanti.
sn56.33:1.2.eng: It’s the same for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving. Sometimes they go from this world to the other world, and sometimes they come from the other world to this world.

sn56.33:1.4.eng: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.

sn56.33:1.6.eng: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.33:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.33:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.34:1.1.pli: “Āditte, bhikkhave, cele vā sīse vā kimassa karaṇīyan”ti?
sn56.34:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if your clothes or head were on fire, what would you do about it?”

sn56.34:1.2.pli: “Āditte, bhante, cele vā sīse vā, tasseva celassa vā sīsassa vā nibbāpanāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyan”ti.
sn56.34:1.2.eng: “Sir, if our clothes or head were on fire, we’d apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness in order to extinguish it.”

sn56.34:2.1.pli: “Ādittaṃ, bhikkhave, celaṃ vā sīsaṃ vā ajjhupekkhitvā amanasikaritvā anabhisametānaṃ catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamayāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
sn56.34:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, so long as you have not encompassed the four noble truths, regard your burning head or clothes with equanimity, ignore them, and apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness to truly comprehending the four noble truths.

sn56.34:2.3.eng: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.34:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.34:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.35:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there was a man with a lifespan of a hundred years.

sn56.35:1.2.eng: And someone might say to him:

sn56.35:1.3.pli: ‘ehambho purisa, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ taṃ sattisatena hanissanti, majjhanhikasamayaṃ sattisatena hanissanti, sāyanhasamayaṃ sattisatena hanissanti.
sn56.35:1.3.eng: ‘Come now, my good man, they’ll strike you with a hundred spears in the morning, at midday, and in the late afternoon.

sn56.35:1.4.pli: So kho tvaṃ, ambho purisa, divase divase tīhi tīhi sattisatehi haññamāno vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī vassasatassa accayena anabhisametāni cattāri ariyasaccāni abhisamessasī’ti.
sn56.35:1.4.eng: And you’ll live for a hundred years being struck with three hundred spears every day. But when a hundred years have passed, you will comprehend the four noble truths for the first time.’

sn56.35:2.1.eng: For an earnest gentleman this is sufficient reason to submit.

sn56.35:2.3.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning.

sn56.35:2.4.pli: pubbā koṭi nappaññāyati sattippahārānaṃ asippahārānaṃ usuppahārānaṃ pharasuppahārānaṃ.
sn56.35:2.4.eng: No first point is found of blows by spears, swords, arrows, and axes.

sn56.35:2.6.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saha dukkhena, saha domanassena catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ abhisamayaṃ vadāmi;
sn56.35:2.6.eng: But the comprehension of the four noble truths doesn’t come with pain or sadness, I say.

sn56.35:2.7.pli: api cāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sahāva sukhena, sahāva somanassena catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ abhisamayaṃ vadāmi.
sn56.35:2.7.eng: Rather, the comprehension of the four noble truths comes only with pleasure and happiness, I say.

sn56.35:2.9.eng: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.35:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.35:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.36:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso yaṃ imasmiṃ jambudīpe tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ tacchetvā ekajjhaṃ saṃhareyya;
sn56.36:1.1.eng: “Suppose a person was to strip all the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in the Black Plum Tree Land, gather them together into one pile,

sn56.36:1.3.pli: Sūlaṃ karitvā ye mahāsamudde mahantakā pāṇā te mahantakesu sūlesu āvuneyya, ye mahāsamudde majjhimakā pāṇā te majjhimakesu sūlesu āvuneyya, ye mahāsamudde sukhumakā pāṇā te sukhumakesu sūlesu āvuneyya.
sn56.36:1.3.eng: Then they’d impale the large creatures in the ocean on large stakes; the medium-sized creatures on medium-sized stakes; and the small creatures on small stakes.

sn56.36:1.4.pli: Apariyādinnā ca, bhikkhave, mahāsamudde oḷārikā pāṇā assu.
sn56.36:1.4.eng: They wouldn’t run out of sizable creatures in the ocean before

sn56.36:2.1.pli: Atha imasmiṃ jambudīpe tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya.
sn56.36:2.1.eng: using up all the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in the Black Plum Tree Land.

sn56.36:2.2.pli: Ito bahutarā kho, bhikkhave, mahāsamudde sukhumakā pāṇā, ye na sukarā sūlesu āvunituṃ.
sn56.36:2.2.eng: There are far more small creatures in the ocean than this, so it wouldn’t be feasible to impale them on stakes.

sn56.36:2.4.eng: Because of the small size of those life-forms.

sn56.36:2.5.eng: That’s how big the plane of loss is.

sn56.36:2.6.pli: Evaṃ mahantasmā kho, bhikkhave, apāyasmā parimutto diṭṭhisampanno puggalo ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn56.36:2.6.eng: An individual accomplished in view, exempt from that vast plane of loss, truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.36:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.36:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.37:1.1.pli: “Sūriyassa, bhikkhave, udayato etaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ etaṃ pubbanimittaṃ, yadidaṃ—aruṇuggaṃ.
sn56.37:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the dawn is the forerunner and precursor of the sunrise.

sn56.37:1.2.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamayāya etaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ etaṃ pubbanimittaṃ, yadidaṃ—sammādiṭṭhi.
sn56.37:1.2.eng: In the same way, right view is the forerunner and precursor of truly comprehending the four noble truths.

sn56.37:1.3.eng: A mendicant with right view can expect to truly understand:

sn56.37:1.4.pli: ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānissati …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānissati.
sn56.37:1.4.eng: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.37:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.37:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.38:1.1.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, candimasūriyā loke nuppajjanti, neva tāva mahato ālokassa pātubhāvo hoti mahato obhāsassa.
sn56.38:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, as long as the moon and the sun don’t arise in the world, no great light or great radiance appears.

sn56.38:1.3.pli: Neva tāva rattindivā paññāyanti, na māsaddhamāsā paññāyanti, na utusaṃvaccharā paññāyanti.
sn56.38:1.3.eng: Day and night aren’t found, nor months and fortnights, nor seasons and years.

sn56.38:2.1.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, candimasūriyā loke uppajjanti, atha mahato ālokassa pātubhāvo hoti mahato obhāsassa.
sn56.38:2.1.eng: But when the moon and the sun arise in the world, a great light, a great radiance appears.

sn56.38:2.2.pli: Neva andhakāratamaṃ tadā hoti na andhakāratimisā.

sn56.38:2.3.pli: Atha rattindivā paññāyanti, māsaddhamāsā paññāyanti, utusaṃvaccharā paññāyanti.
sn56.38:2.3.eng: Day and night are found, and months and fortnights, and seasons and years.

sn56.38:2.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yāvakīvañca tathāgato loke nuppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, neva tāva mahato ālokassa pātubhāvo hoti mahato obhāsassa.
sn56.38:2.4.eng: In the same way, as long as the Realized One doesn’t arise in the world, no great light or great radiance appears.

sn56.38:2.6.pli: Neva tāva catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ ācikkhaṇā hoti desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ.
sn56.38:2.6.eng: There’s no explanation of the four noble truths, no teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of them.

sn56.38:3.1.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, atha mahato ālokassa pātubhāvo hoti mahato obhāsassa.
sn56.38:3.1.eng: But when the Realized One arises in the world, a great light, a great radiance appears.

sn56.38:3.2.pli: Neva andhatamaṃ tadā hoti na andhakāratimisā.

sn56.38:3.3.pli: Atha kho catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ ācikkhaṇā hoti desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ.
sn56.38:3.3.eng: Then there’s the explanation of the four noble truths, the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of them.

sn56.38:3.5.eng: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.38:4.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.38:4.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.39:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn56.39:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.39:1.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, te aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā mukhaṃ ullokenti:
sn56.39:1.2.eng: They gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:

sn56.39:1.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ nūna bhavaṃ jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī’ti.
sn56.39:1.3.eng: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’

sn56.39:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, tūlapicu vā kappāsapicu vā lahuko vātūpādāno same bhūmibhāge nikkhitto.
sn56.39:2.1.eng: Suppose there was a light tuft of cotton-wool or kapok which was taken up by the wind and landed on level ground.

sn56.39:2.2.pli: Tamenaṃ puratthimo vāto pacchimena saṃhareyya, pacchimo vāto puratthimena saṃhareyya, uttaro vāto dakkhiṇena saṃhareyya, dakkhiṇo vāto uttarena saṃhareyya.
sn56.39:2.2.eng: The east wind wafts it west; the west wind wafts it east; the north wind wafts it south; and the south wind wafts it north.

sn56.39:2.4.eng: It’s because the tuft of cotton-wool is so light.

sn56.39:2.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn56.39:2.5.eng: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.39:2.6.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, te aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā mukhaṃ ullokenti:
sn56.39:2.6.eng: They gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:

sn56.39:2.7.pli: ‘ayaṃ nūna bhavaṃ jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī’ti.
sn56.39:2.7.eng: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’

sn56.39:2.9.eng: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.

sn56.39:3.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti …pe…
sn56.39:3.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.39:3.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, te na aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā mukhaṃ ullokenti:
sn56.39:3.2.eng: They don’t gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:

sn56.39:3.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ nūna bhavaṃ jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī’ti.
sn56.39:3.3.eng: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’

sn56.39:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ayokhīlo vā indakhīlo vā gambhīranemo sunikhāto acalo asampakampī.
sn56.39:4.1.eng: Suppose there was an iron pillar or an Indra’s pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.

sn56.39:4.2.pli: Puratthimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi, neva saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampacāleyya; pacchimāya cepi disāya …pe… uttarāya cepi disāya …pe… dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi, neva saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampacāleyya.
sn56.39:4.2.eng: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south, they couldn’t make it shake or rock or tremble.

sn56.39:4.4.eng: It’s because that Indra’s pillar is firmly embedded, with deep foundations.

sn56.39:4.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye ca kho keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti …pe…
sn56.39:4.5.eng: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.39:4.6.pli: ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, te na aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā mukhaṃ ullokenti:
sn56.39:4.6.eng: They don’t gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:

sn56.39:4.7.pli: ‘ayaṃ nūna bhavaṃ jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī’ti.
sn56.39:4.7.eng: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’

sn56.39:4.9.eng: It’s because they have clearly seen the four noble truths.

sn56.39:4.11.eng: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.39:5.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.39:5.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.4:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ kulaputtā sammā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā yathābhūtaṃ abhisamesuṃ, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisamesuṃ.

sn56.4:1.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ kulaputtā sammā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā yathābhūtaṃ abhisamessanti, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisamessanti.

sn56.4:1.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi kulaputtā sammā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā yathābhūtaṃ abhisamenti, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisamenti.
sn56.4:1.3.eng: or present—truly comprehend after rightly going forth from the lay life to homelessness, all of them truly comprehend the four noble truths.

sn56.4:2.2.pli: Dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
sn56.4:2.2.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. …

sn56.4:2.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ kulaputtā sammā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā yathābhūtaṃ abhisamesuṃ …pe…

sn56.4:2.5.pli: abhisamenti, sabbe te imāni cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisamenti.

sn56.4:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.4:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.40:1.1.pli: “Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe…
sn56.40:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, take any mendicant who truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.40:1.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, puratthimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā vādatthiko vādagavesī:
sn56.40:1.2.eng: An ascetic or brahmin might come from the east, west, north, or south wanting to debate, seeking a debate, thinking:

sn56.40:1.3.pli: ‘vādamassa āropessāmī’ti, taṃ vata sahadhammena saṅkampessati vā sampakampessati vā sampacālessati vāti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn56.40:1.3.eng: ‘I’ll refute their doctrine!’ It’s simply impossible for them to legitimately make that mendicant shake or rock or tremble.

sn56.40:1.6.pli: dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā vādatthiko vādagavesī:

sn56.40:1.7.pli: ‘vādamassa āropessāmī’ti, taṃ vata sahadhammena saṅkampessati vā sampakampessati vā sampacālessati vāti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

sn56.40:2.1.eng: Suppose there was a stone pillar, sixteen feet long.

sn56.40:2.2.pli: Tassassu aṭṭha kukku heṭṭhā nemaṅgamā, aṭṭha kukku uparinemassa.
sn56.40:2.2.eng: Eight feet were buried underground, and eight above ground.

sn56.40:2.3.pli: Puratthimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi, neva saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampacāleyya; pacchimāya cepi disāya …pe… uttarāya cepi disāya …pe… dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi, neva saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampacāleyya.
sn56.40:2.3.eng: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south, they couldn’t make it shake or rock or tremble.

sn56.40:2.5.eng: It’s because that stone pillar is firmly embedded, with deep foundations.

sn56.40:2.6.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yo hi koci bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
sn56.40:2.6.eng: In the same way, take any mendicant who truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.40:2.7.pli: puratthimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā vādatthiko vādagavesī ‘vādamassa āropessāmī’ti, taṃ vata sahadhammena saṅkampessati vā sampakampessati vā sampacālessati vāti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn56.40:2.7.eng: An ascetic or brahmin might come from the east, west, north, or south wanting to debate, seeking a debate, thinking: ‘I’ll refute their doctrine!’ It’s simply impossible for them to legitimately make that mendicant shake or rock or tremble.

sn56.40:2.10.pli: dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā vādatthiko vādagavesī: ‘vādamassa āropessāmī’ti, taṃ vata sahadhammena saṅkampessati vā sampakampessati vā sampacālessati vāti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

sn56.40:2.12.eng: It’s because they have clearly seen the four noble truths.

sn56.40:2.14.eng: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.40:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.40:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.41:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn56.41:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn56.41:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn56.41:1.3.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, aññataro puriso rājagahā nikkhamitvā ‘lokacintaṃ cintessāmī’ti yena sumāgadhā pokkharaṇī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sumāgadhāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre nisīdi lokacintaṃ cintento.
sn56.41:1.3.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a certain person left Rājagaha, thinking ‘I’ll speculate about the world.’ They went to the Sumāgadhā lotus pond and sat down on the bank speculating about the world.

sn56.41:1.4.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, so puriso sumāgadhāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ bhisamuḷālaṃ pavisantaṃ.
sn56.41:1.4.eng: Then that person saw an army of four divisions enter a lotus stalk.

sn56.41:1.5.eng: When he saw this he thought,

sn56.41:1.6.eng: ‘I’ve gone mad, really, I’ve lost my mind!

sn56.41:1.7.pli: Yaṃ loke natthi taṃ mayā diṭṭhan’ti.
sn56.41:1.7.eng: I’m seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’

sn56.41:2.1.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso nagaraṃ pavisitvā mahājanakāyassa ārocesi:
sn56.41:2.1.eng: Then that person entered the city and informed a large crowd,

sn56.41:2.2.eng: ‘I’ve gone mad, really, I’ve lost my mind!

sn56.41:2.3.pli: Yaṃ loke natthi taṃ mayā diṭṭhan’ti.
sn56.41:2.3.eng: I’m seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’

sn56.41:2.4.pli: ‘Kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, ambho purisa, ummatto kathaṃ viceto?
sn56.41:2.4.eng: ‘But how is it that you’re mad? How have you lost your mind?

sn56.41:2.5.pli: Kiñca loke natthi yaṃ tayā diṭṭhan’ti?
sn56.41:2.5.eng: And what have you seen that doesn’t exist in the world?’

sn56.41:2.6.pli: ‘Idhāhaṃ, bhante, rājagahā nikkhamitvā “lokacintaṃ cintessāmī”ti yena sumāgadhā pokkharaṇī tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā sumāgadhāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre nisīdiṃ lokacintaṃ cintento.
sn56.41:2.6.eng: ‘Sirs, I left Rājagaha, thinking “I’ll speculate about the world.” I went to the Sumāgadhā lotus pond and sat down on the bank speculating about the world.

sn56.41:2.7.pli: Addasaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, sumāgadhāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ bhisamuḷālaṃ pavisantaṃ.
sn56.41:2.7.eng: Then I saw an army of four divisions enter a lotus stalk.

sn56.41:2.8.pli: Evaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, ummatto evaṃ viceto.
sn56.41:2.8.eng: That’s why I’m mad, that’s why I’ve lost my mind.

sn56.41:2.9.pli: Idañca loke natthi yaṃ mayā diṭṭhan’ti.
sn56.41:2.9.eng: And that’s what I’ve seen that doesn’t exist in the world.’

sn56.41:2.10.pli: ‘Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, ummatto taggha viceto.
sn56.41:2.10.eng: ‘Well, worthy man, you’re definitely mad, you’ve definitely lost your mind.

sn56.41:2.11.pli: Idañca loke natthi yaṃ tayā diṭṭhan’ti.
sn56.41:2.11.eng: And you’re seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’

sn56.41:3.1.pli: Taṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, so puriso bhūtaṃyeva addasa, no abhūtaṃ.
sn56.41:3.1.eng: But what that person saw was in fact real, not unreal.

sn56.41:3.2.eng: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

sn56.41:3.3.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājiniṃsu.
sn56.41:3.3.eng: In that battle the gods won and the titans lost.

sn56.41:3.4.pli: Parājitā ca kho, bhikkhave, asurā bhītā bhisamuḷālena asurapuraṃ pavisiṃsu devānaṃyeva mohayamānā.
sn56.41:3.4.eng: The defeated and terrified titans entered the citadel of the titans through the lotus stalk only to confuse the gods.

sn56.41:4.1.eng: So mendicants, don’t speculate about the world.

sn56.41:4.2.pli: ‘sassato loko’ti vā ‘asassato loko’ti vā, ‘antavā loko’ti vā ‘anantavā loko’ti vā, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti vā, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā.
sn56.41:4.2.eng: For example: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are one and the same, or the soul is one thing, the body another; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.

sn56.41:4.4.pli: Nesā, bhikkhave, cintā atthasaṃhitā nādibrahmacariyakā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn56.41:4.4.eng: Because those thoughts aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.41:5.1.pli: Cintentā kho tumhe, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti cinteyyātha …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti cinteyyātha.
sn56.41:5.1.eng: When you think something up, you should think: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.41:5.3.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, cintā atthasaṃhitā esā ādibrahmacariyakā esā nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn56.41:5.3.eng: Because those thoughts are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.41:6.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.41:6.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
